Graphical abstract A systematic study on titania-supported nickel catalysts was performed in order to evaluate the effect of different process conditions on catalyst stability. Reaction tests and temperature-programmed-hydrogenation analyses were used in order to evaluate the effect of temperature, feed composition, water and reduction conditions on catalyst deactivation and carbon deposition. It was shown that high H2/CO ratios and syngas partial pressures decrease the rate of carbon formation. Moreover, increasing temperature enhanced the formation of more stable carbon species and thus catalyst deactivation. The temperature-programmed hydrogenation analyses also revealed that water reduces the rate of carbon deposition. However, water enhanced catalyst deactivation when the catalysts were reduced at high temperatures. This negative effect of water is probably due to a progressive destruction of the strong-metal-support interaction characteristic of titania-supported nickel catalysts reduced at high temperatures. Keywords Methanation Deactivation Nickel Titania Carbon formation 1 Introduction Synthetic natural gas (SNG) production from coal and biomass has attracted particular attention due to the increasing demand of natural gas and the imminent depletion of this fossil source [1–3]. Moreover, the use of biomass for this purpose can improve the security in the energy supply and, at the same time, reduce anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions [4–6]. The conventional route for SNG production is based on the conversion of carbon feedstocks into synthesis gas via gasification and its subsequent catalytic conversion to SNG via methanation [7,8]. Methanation is a key step in the production of SNG and great efforts are made in the development of efficient catalysts [9–14] and reactor systems [15–20]. Among all the materials which catalyze the methanation reaction, nickel-based catalysts are preferred due to their high activity, selectivity towards methane and relatively low cost [21,22]. Nevertheless, the stability of nickel-based catalysts is threatened by multiple causes of deactivation occurring at different operating conditions. At low temperatures (473–573K) and high CO partial pressures, there is a high risk for nickel carbonyl formation which results in the loss of nickel and/or nickel particle sintering [23,24]. At moderately high temperatures (up to 723K) there is a potential for formation of polymeric carbon, also known as “gum” formation [3,25–28]. At higher temperatures (>773K) activity decay can occur due to thermal sintering of the support [29], formation of whisker carbon [30–33] and/or nickel crystal growth due to particle migration and mitigation [34]. Moreover, the presence of impurities in the feed gas, such as sulfur compounds, can also result in a severe loss of activity [35]. Therefore, catalyst optimization aims for materials with high stability under a wide range of conditions [21]. Alumina-supported nickel catalysts are, probably, the most used methanation catalysts due to their satisfactory activity and stability [2,36,37]. The effect of different operating parameters on the deactivation of Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts has also been widely studied. Shen et al. [23] studied the effect of temperature and CO partial pressure on nickel carbonyl formation. Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts have also been used to study carbon formation [25–28] and sulfur poisoning [35,38,39]. It is also important to mention the work of Bartholomew et al. [29] in which they investigated the effect of different parameters such as temperature, presence of water and alumina physicochemical properties on sintering. In the recent years, further work on catalyst development has been done and several studies have found catalysts exhibiting better performance than Ni/Al2O3. For instance, Guo et al. [40] reported that the addition of ZrO2 to Ni/Al2O3 catalysts enhances the resistance against carbon formation and sintering. Moreover, Zhang et al. [13,41] have recently compared Ni/SiC with Ni/Al2O3 and have found higher stability on Ni/SiC. In addition, Jia et al. [42] found higher stability on Ni/CaTiO3 than on Ni/Al2O3 catalysts under high temperature conditions. Finally, in our previous work [43], it was also found that Ni/TiO2 catalysts can exhibit significantly higher resistance towards carbon formation and nickel particle sintering than other supported catalysts under low temperature conditions. Moreover, the influence of different operating parameters on the deactivation of different supported catalysts could differ from that already studied on Ni/γ-Al2O3. For instance, TiO2-supported nickel catalysts present higher resistance towards nickel carbonyl formation than SiO2-supported nickel catalysts [43,44]. Metal-support interactions can also have an effect on the amount and type of carbon formed [43,45–47]. Furthermore, the conditions at which support sintering and phase transformation occur vary with different carriers [48–51]. Finally, it was shown in our previous study [43] that different amounts and species of carbon form for different supported nickel catalysts. Therefore, investigation on the effect of operating conditions on the stability of different catalysts is worthwhile. Furthermore, methanation is performed at a very wide range of conditions [1,52]. For instance, it can be performed adiabatically (such as in the TREMP™ process [3,20,53]), or quasi-isothermally (such as in fluidized bed reactor concepts [54–56]). As a result, methanation is practiced in a temperature range of 200 to 700°C and pressures from 20 to 60bar [1,52]. Indeed, it is not surprising to find in literature different procedures and reaction conditions to evaluate methanation catalysts, fact that complicates the comparison between catalysts from different studies. Once more, a good understanding of the effect of reaction parameters on the deactivation of different catalysts would help these comparisons. In this work, two different Ni/TiO2 catalysts were prepared and systematically tested under different methanation conditions. The aim of this study is to evaluate the effect of catalyst reduction conditions, reaction temperature, pressure, syngas composition and presence of water on catalyst deactivation and specially, on carbon formation. 2 Methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation Two titania-supported nickel catalysts were prepared by using incipient wetness impregnation. The Ni loading in both catalysts was 20wt%. The TiO2 (Degussa P25) support material was first dried at 393K for 6h and then calcined in flowing air for 10h at 973K (ramp=1K/min). After calcination, the support material was impregnated with an aqueous solution of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (puriss. p.a.; ≥98.5% (KT), Fluka), dried for 3h at 393K and subsequently calcined in air at 723K for 3h (heating rate: 2.5K/min). The two prepared catalysts were named 20Ni/TiO2 batch 1 and 20Ni/TiO2 batch 2. These two catalyst batches were also used in our previous work [43]. The volume of aqueous solution required to dissolve the nickel salt was higher than the pore volume of the support. Therefore, the aqueous solution was deposited batch wise, drying the samples at 393K for 2h after every deposition. The same volume of Ni(NO3)2 aqueous solution was employed for both catalysts. The only difference in the preparation procedure between these two batches was the total number of depositions with intermediate drying used to complete the impregnation. A larger number of depositions was employed in the preparation of 20Ni/TiO2 batch 2. 2.2 Catalyst characterization techniques A Micromeritics Mercury Porosimeter, AutoPore IV was used in order to characterize the TiO2 support and the catalyst samples where the macropore contribution to the pore volume and surface area is significant. The degree of reduction (DoR) was estimated from temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) after in situ reduction of the samples and subsequent purging with helium for 1h at the reduction temperature. The TPR of the samples was performed at a heating rate of 10K/min up to 1203K in a flow of 5% H2 in Ar while monitoring the difference on thermal conductivity between the inlet and outlet gas. The thermal conductivity detector (TCD) signal was calibrated by the reduction of Ag2O powder. The DoR was calculated assuming that the unreduced nickel was composed of Ni (II) as evidenced from X-ray diffraction. The DoR calculation procedure has been described in [57]. Hydrogen static chemisorption was performed on the reduced catalysts in order to estimate the nickel dispersion (D H, %) and the nickel crystallite size (d(Ni0)H, nm). The chemisorption measurements were conducted on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020C unit at 308K, after reducing about 0.15g of the calcined catalyst samples in flowing H2 at different conditions. The average particle size of Ni was calculated according to [58]: (1) d ( N i 0 ) H = 97 D H × DoR X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed on a Siemens D5000 difractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (2θ =10–90°, step size=0.02°) equipped with a Ni filter. The measurements were carried out both after calcination and after reduction and passivation of the catalyst samples. Average crystallite diameter of Ni (d(Ni0)XRD, nm) and NiO (d(NiO)XRD, nm) were estimated by using the Scherrer formula and assuming spherical particles [59]. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained using a JEOL JEM 1400 microscope. All samples were mounted on 3mm holey carbon copper grids. The average particle size was calculated with 80–100 particles. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data were recorded on 4mm×4mm pellets 0.5mm thick that were obtained by gently pressing the powdered materials following outgassing to a pressure below about 2×10−8 Torr at 423K in the instrument pre-chamber to remove chemisorbed volatile species. The main chamber of the Leibold–Heraeus LHS10 spectrometer used, capable of operating down to less than 2×10−9 Torr, was equipped with an EA-200MCD hemispherical electron analyzer with a dual X-ray source using AlKα (hv=1486.6eV) at 120W, at 30mA, with C(1s) as energy reference (284.6eV). Elemental analysis of metal-containing samples was performed by the staff at the Central Service for Research Support (SCAI) of the University of Córdoba. It was performed using inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). Measurements were made on a PerkinElmer ELAN DRC-e instrument following dissolution of the sample in a 1:3HNO3/HCl mixture with a soft heating. Calibration was done by using PE Pure Plus atomic spectroscopy standards, also from PerkinElmer. Elemental analysis of metal-containing samples was performed by the staff at the Central Service for Research Support (SCAI) of the University of Córdoba. It was performed using inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). Measurements were made on a PerkinElmer ELAN DRC-e instrument, which calibration was done by using PE Pure Plus atomic spectroscopy standards, also from PerkinElmer. Firstly, 100mg of sample were dissolved in 5ml of a solution consisting of a 1:3HNO3/HCl mixture with a soft heating (approximately 323K). Then, the solution was diluted with ultra-pure water until reaching a concentration of 100ppm of Ni. Temperature-programmed hydrogenation (TPH) was performed on the spent samples in order to study the type and amount of carbon present after reaction. The TPH of the samples was performed in situ by passing a flow of pure H2 (233Nml/mingcat) through the catalyst bed while increasing the temperature at a heating rate of 5K/min up to 963K. The evolution of methane was monitored during the treatment with a HiQuad™ QMG700 mass spectrometer (m/z =15, instead of 16 to avoid the interference of ionized oxygen from water vapor as in [60]). The pressure in the MS chamber, the SEM voltage and the signal reading time were set, respectively, at 5×10−6 mbar, 2000kV and 1s for all the experiments. 2.3 Catalytic testing The methanation tests were performed in a down-flow stainless steel fixed-bed reactor (i.d. 9mm) with a catalyst loading of 0.1–0.25g (pellet size: 53–90μm) diluted with a minimum 3.5g of SiC (average pellet size: 75μm). As already mentioned in the introduction section, different operating conditions were studied. Nevertheless, the major part of the experiments were performed at 583K, at a maximum pressure of 20bar and a molar inlet H2/CO ratio of 3. At these conditions, the small pellet size used for the methanation catalysts ensured the absence of any mass transfer limitations. A maximum intraparticle temperature difference of 1K was estimated by using the method described by Satterfield [61]. The reactor was heated by means of an oven and the catalyst bed temperature was regulated by cascade control with two thermocouples: one sliding thermocouple placed inside the catalyst bed and another one placed in the oven. This diluted reaction system, together with an aluminum jacket placed between the reactor and the oven, allowed for a quasi-isothermal operation. The observed variation in temperature along the catalyst bed was approximately ±2K in all the experiments. A more detailed description of the equipment is given in [62–64]. Prior to reaction, the catalyst was reduced in situ in pure H2 (450Nml/mingcat) at atmospheric pressure at 773K (heating rate: 5K/min) for 4h. After reduction, the catalyst was cooled to reaction temperature and then flushed with He before increasing the pressure to the desired level. Afterwards, the methanation experiments started with a stepwise increase of the syngas flow, together with a stepwise decrease of the He flow, in order to avoid a large temperature rise in the catalyst bed due to the exothermic reaction. The syngas feed contained between 1 and 3% of N2 as an internal standard. A systematic study was performed on the 20Ni/TiO2 batch 1. The different operating conditions used in this study are presented in Table 1 . As can be expected, variations in operating conditions such as temperature, composition and pressure will result in different kinetic rates. Therefore, different gas-hourly space velocities (GHSV) were used in these experiments in order to ensure a kinetically controlled CO conversion (the CO conversion at equilibrium is practically 100% at these conditions [21,52]). For all the experiments, the reaction was stopped after 6h on stream in order to compare, by means of TPH, carbon formation between different experiments. Furthermore, the 20Ni/TiO2 batch 2 was used in two different runs which lasted for longer times on stream. In one of the runs the catalyst was reduced at 773K for 4h while for the other run it was reduced at 573K for 16h (heating rate: 5K/min for both experiments). Different operating conditions were used during these runs in order to better evaluate the effect of different variables on the deactivation rate. The different operating conditions used in these two experiments are described in Tables 2 and 3 for the samples reduced at 773K and 573K, respectively. The gas products were analyzed on-line using a GC Agilent 6890 equipped with a TCD and a flame ionization detector (FID). H2, N2, CO, CH4 and CO2 were separated by a Carbosieve II packed column and analyzed on the TCD. C1–C6 hydrocarbons were separated by an alumina-plot column and quantified on the FID. Further description of the product analysis and data treatment is given in [64]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of supports and catalysts Table 4 shows the physical properties of the support material and the catalysts after calcination. These materials are characterized by their low surface area and large pores. Table 5 summarizes the physicochemical properties of the two studied catalysts after different reduction conditions. Figs. 1 and 2 present representative TEM images of the 20Ni/TiO2 batch 2 after reduction at 773K and 573K, respectively, which have been used to estimate the average nickel particle size. The images allow for a clear distinction between nickel crystallites and the titania support. The Ni average particle diameter was estimated from H2 static chemisorption, X-ray diffraction and transmission electron microscopy. As can be seen in Table 5, the two catalyst batches differed in Ni particle size. This difference is due to the different number of aqueous solution depositions during the impregnation as explained in the catalyst preparation section. Moreover, the measurements predicted by H2 chemisorption deviate significantly from those obtained by XRD and TEM. This phenomenon has been observed in other studies which use titania-supported catalysts and has been explained by a decrease of the H2 and CO adsorption properties due to the presence of a strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) [44,65–67]. It has been suggested that the reduction at high temperatures (around 773K) leads to the formation of intermetallic compounds [68] and/or partially reduced titania species (TiOx, x <2) [47,69] which are responsible for these phenomena. Another interesting observation is the difference in metal dispersion (DH) between the two catalyst batches. The metal dispersion after reduction at 773K is higher for the “batch 1” than for the “batch 2”. This difference can be explained by their difference in average nickel particle size. According to Van de Loosdrecht et al. [47], these TiO x species can form on small nickel crystallites after reduction at low temperatures. In other words, this metal-support interaction is more severe for small Ni particles. Thus, it is reasonable that the chemisorption of H2 is weaker for the 20/NiTiO2 batch 2. In attempting to understand the influence of the reduction temperature on the presence of this SMSI, the 20 Ni/TIO2 batch 2 was exposed to a series of reduction treatments at different temperatures with intermediate H2 static chemisorption analyses. First, the catalyst was in situ reduced at 573K for 4h and analyzed. The obtained nickel dispersion was D H =1.3 %. Subsequently, the same sample was reduced at 673K for 4h. The measured nickel dispersion was then DH =1.2 %. Finally, the sample was reduced at 773K for 4h. No available nickel surface area was observed after this last treatment. Conclusively, these H2-chemisorption analyses in series showed that this SMSI is definitely present after reduction at 773K. This statement is further supported by the difference in Ni wt% estimated from XPS, which is an indication of the Ni content in the catalyst surface. As can be seen in Table 5, the estimated nickel content is lower after reduction at 773K fact that indicates that the nickel surface is partially covered by TiO x species. Finally, it is worthwhile mentioning that the dispersion values obtained after reduction at 573K and 673K are still very low and the corresponding nickel crystal sizes are still larger than those observed by TEM measurements. In consequence, it is possible that this SMSI is also present after reduction at lower temperatures, however, to a lesser extent. 3.2 Effect of H2/CO ratio and syngas partial pressure As mentioned previously, the 20Ni/TIO2 batch 1 was used in a systematic study in order to evaluate the effect of different reaction conditions. This section presents and compares the experiments performed using different inlet H2/CO ratios and syngas partial pressures. In Fig. 3 , the CO conversion as a function of time on stream is presented for the experiments performed at 583K, atmospheric pressure and different inlet H2/CO ratios. This figure shows that the CO conversion, and thus the catalyst activity, is higher when using higher H2/CO ratios. In the previous work from Vannice [67,70,71], it was found that H2 and CO have, respectively, a positive and negative kinetic effect on the methanation rate. It was, therefore, not surprising to observe this difference in catalyst activity for these experiments. Furthermore, it can be deduced from Fig. 3 that the catalyst presents more stability when it is exposed to high H2/CO ratios. Two main deactivation phenomena are likely to occur at these low-temperature conditions: nickel carbonyl-promoted sintering and carbon deposition. Nevertheless, the formation of nickel carbonyls at these low CO partial pressures should be significantly suppressed [23]. In consequence, differences in carbon formation should explain the differences observed in catalyst stability. After 6h of reaction, the catalyst was cooled down to room temperature in helium. Afterwards, TPH was performed in situ on the catalyst samples at atmospheric pressure. The TPH profiles presented in Fig. 4 were obtained after the experiments presented in Fig. 3. As can be deduced from this figure, there is a clear effect of the inlet H2/CO ratio on the amount and species of carbon formed. On one hand, it can be concluded that the rate of carbon formation decreases with increasing H2/CO ratio. On the other hand, it can be observed that low H2/CO ratios lead to the formation of more stable carbon species. According to Bartholomew [27,28], three carbon species can form at the employed reaction temperature: atomic carbon (Cα), polymeric carbon (Cβ) and vermicular filaments (C v) presenting hydrogenation peaks at 473K, 673K and 673–873K, respectively [26–28]. The TPH profile of the experiment which used a H2/CO ratio=9 presents, mainly, a hydrogenation peak around 450K. This carbon specie can be identified as atomic carbon. The other experiments present their main hydrogenation peak at a temperature between 550 and 600K. According to the hydrogenating peak temperatures defined previously, the nature of these carbon species is uncertain. Nevertheless, this carbon species is hydrogenating around the reaction temperature. This can suggest that this species is atomic carbon which remained adsorbed on the nickel surface when the reaction was stopped. However, this statement contradicts the fact that, atomic carbon could be hydrogenated at much lower temperatures for the experiment performed using a H2/CO ratio=9. Moreover, it can be deduced from the TPH profile of the experiment performed using a H2/CO ratio=6 that another carbon species hydrogenating around 473K is present. In addition, this distinction between these two mentioned carbon species hydrogenating below the reaction temperature was also observed in our previous work [43]. Thereby, the authors suggest that this carbon specie hydrogenating between 550 and 600K is a type of polymeric carbon and is responsible for catalyst deactivation. Furthermore, the TPH profiles of the experiments performed using H2/CO ratios of 2, 3 and 6 present other hydrogenation peaks at temperatures between 600 and 800K. These type of carbon species can be identified as Cβ. However, some of these carbon species, especially those hydrogenating around 800K, could be identified as C v. It must be mentioned though, that this identification of carbon deposits is based only on the hydrogenation peak temperatures from literature [27,28]. Hence, the nature of these carbon species is uncertain. The experiment “Exp. 2” (inlet H2/CO ratio=3, P =1bar and T =583K) was repeated in order to analyze the spent sample by TEM and ICP-MS. The nickel loading obtained was 19.5% and no appreciable growth of the Ni particles was observed in the TEM images. Therefore, it could be concluded that no significant carbonyl-induced sintering neither Ni loss occurs for the experiments performed at atmospheric pressure. In Fig. 5 , the CO conversion as a function of time on stream is presented for the experiments performed at 20bar, 583K and different inlet H2/CO ratios. Once more, the catalyst exhibited higher activity and stability when exposed to higher H2/CO ratios. It must be noticed that the CO partial pressures in the presented experiments were considerably higher than those performed at atmospheric pressure. Therefore, there is a higher risk for nickel carbonyl formation or for a carbonyl induced sintering. In consequence, the inlet H2/CO ratio and thus, the inlet CO partial pressure are expected to have a significant effect on catalyst stability. After reaction, the catalysts were cooled down to room temperature in helium and brought down to atmospheric pressure in order to perform TPH in situ on the spent samples. Fig. 6 presents the TPH profiles obtained after the experiments presented in Figs. 3 and 5. It can be deduced from this figure that the amount of carbon formed is significantly reduced when operating at higher syngas partial pressures. Moreover, it can also be deduced that the main carbon specie formed on the nickel surface at high syngas partial pressures, during this 6h of reaction, is Cα. Fig. 6 reveals that the formation of polymeric carbon hydrogenating at 600K and 800K is significantly reduced when operating at high pressures. It is important though, not to conclude that polymeric carbon formation is completely suppressed at 20bar. In our previous work [43], it was shown that the dominant carbon species after 2h of reaction was Cα whereas, after 24h, the dominant species was that hydrogenating at 600K. Therefore, larger amounts of this type of polymeric carbon would be observed in the TPH profiles if the reaction was stopped at longer time on streams. The small amounts of polymeric carbon obtained in the high pressure experiments do not allow for a clear evaluation of the effect of H2/CO ratio. Indeed, the main difference between these experiments is the amount of Cα on the nickel surface, which is not directly related to catalyst deactivation. The effect of H2/CO ratio at high pressure was then evaluated by comparing deactivation rates, however, at longer time on streams when the deactivation due to nickel particle sintering is less significant. In Fig. 7 , the CO conversion as a function of time on stream is plotted for two different periods. The H2/CO ratios used were 3 and 6 for the first and second period, respectively. The deactivation rates, expressed in CO conversion loss per hour, are presented in the figure next to each period in order to better evaluate the effect of H2/CO ratio on catalyst deactivation. The figure shows that, at longer time on streams, the inlet H2/CO ratio has a small effect on catalyst deactivation, as it could be predicted from the carbon formation study at atmospheric pressure. 3.3 Effect of temperature This section presents and compares the experiments performed at different temperatures. In Fig. 8 , the CO conversion during methanation synthesis is plotted for the experiments performed at atmospheric pressure and three different temperatures: 553, 583 and 613K. Before analyzing the figure, it should be noticed that different GHSV were employed for these 3 experiments in order to expose the catalyst to kinetically controlled CO conversions. These GHSV were also defined based on expected activities with varying temperature in order to work at sufficiently high CO conversions that allow for a decent evaluation of the deactivation profiles. The figure reveals that the CO conversion obtained after 6h for the experiment performed at 613K was unexpectedly low. In order to evaluate that, it must be noticed that the employed space velocity was about 3 times higher than that employed at 583K. Moreover, the apparent activation energy of this reaction has been estimated in, approximately, 102kJ/mol [72,73]. Taking these two arguments into account, a higher CO conversion was expected when operating at 613K. This figure reveals, thereby, that the catalyst deactivated considerably faster at 613K than at the other temperatures. As described previously, TPH was performed on the spent samples after reaction. Fig. 9 presents the TPH profiles obtained after the experiments presented in Fig. 8. It can be deduced from the figure that the amount of carbon formed increased with increasing temperature. It can also be clearly observed that the formation rate of the carbon species hydrogenating around 750–800K was significantly high for the experiment performed at 613K, fact that can justify the differences in catalyst stability observed in Fig. 8. In the work of Sughrue et al. [73], they hypothesized three different mechanistic regions for CO methanation on nickel-based catalysts. According to the mentioned study, H2 adsorption is the rate-limiting step between 475 and 525K; CO dissociation and carbon hydrogenation are rate-limiting between 525 and 575K and; at temperatures above 575K, carbon hydrogenation is rate-determining. Thereby, it is probable that the rate of carbon polymerization increases significantly at temperatures above 575K, fact that is in agreement with the TPH results shown in Fig. 9. The effect of temperature on catalyst deactivation was also evaluated at high syngas partial pressures at longer times on stream. The effect of temperature on catalyst stability is illustrated in Fig. 10 . The results show that the deactivation rate is significantly higher when increasing the temperature from 583K to 613K. This phenomenon can be justified with the previous information obtained at atmospheric pressure. This significant acceleration of the deactivation rate is most probably due to an increase in the formation rate of this stable carbon species which hydrogenated around 750–800K. 3.4 Effect of water It is generally known that water, the major by-product in CO hydrogenation reactions, accelerates the deactivation of Fischer–Tropsch catalysts [58,74,75]. On one hand iron-based FT catalysts suffer from hydrothermal sintering when operating at high conversions, and so exposing the catalysts to high water partial pressures [76]. On the other hand, water has shown to enhance the oxidation of small clusters and the formation of inactive metal-support spinel species in cobalt-based FT catalysts [74,77–79]. Indeed, it is generally recommended to keep the water partial pressure below 5–6 atm by operating at CO conversions lower than 50–60% and/or using series of reactors with intermediate water removal [58]. In literature, studies concerning the effect of water on the stability of nickel-based methanation catalysts are, to the best of our knowledge, rather scarce. Bartholomew et al. [29] studied sintering of alumina-supported nickel catalysts in H2/H2O atmospheres. In contrast with the present work, that study was performed at considerably high temperatures and low concentrations of water. In the work of Mirodatos et al. [46], they also evaluated the effect of H2O on sintering. In agreement with Bartholomew et al. [29] they found that water does not induce sintering of nickel at low temperatures. However, it must be mentioned that this was evaluated at atmospheric pressure. Furthermore, it is generally accepted that water reduces the rates of carbon deposition [80]. In other words, water enhances the rate of carbon gasification [81]. Indeed, steam is co-fed with synthesis gas in some industrial coal-to-SNG applications in order to thermodynamically inhibit carbon deposition [80,82]. In this section, the effect of water is discussed by comparing the experiments performed at 20bar, 583K and different H2/CO ratios. Fig. 11 presents the CO conversion as a function of time on stream for experiments in which either steam or helium was mixed with the synthesis gas feed. A lower water concentration was employed for a H2/CO ratio=3 in order to evaluate if water has the same effect for different inlet concentrations. The figure reveals an evident negative effect of water on the resulting catalyst activity after 6h on stream. These results indicate that, for all the tested H2/CO ratios, water enhances catalyst deactivation and/or has a negative kinetic effect. As performed in the previous sections, TPH was done on the spent samples in order to qualitatively compare the amounts and species of carbon formed on the catalyst surface. Fig. 12 presents the TPH profiles obtained after the experiments presented in Fig. 11. It can be deduced from this figure that, as expected, water partially removes the amount of carbon present on the catalyst. It would be noteworthy to mention that, according to the authors of the present work, the only carbon specie found on these TPH profiles is Cα since the hydrogenation peak temperatures of these profiles are close to 473K. In this sense, we doubt that water could present any positive influence on catalyst stability during this 6h on stream. The spent samples were analyzed with XRD in order to evaluate if water could enhance sintering of the nickel particles. Table 6 presents the calculated nickel crystal sizes obtained after the experiments presented in Fig. 11. It can be clearly deduced that H2O does not enhance sintering of nickel particles at the employed operating conditions. Furthermore, no NiO neither NiTiO3 compounds could be observed in any of these difractograms. As previously presented, different water and helium feed concentrations were employed in a longer test in order to better evaluate the effect of water on the performance of Ni/TiO2 catalysts. Fig. 13 presents the CO conversion as a function of time on stream for these periods in which water and helium were co-fed with synthesis gas. In the first presented period the synthesis gas feed contained 20% He. In the next period, the synthesis gas feed contained 10% He and 10% H2O. Then, the flow of He was completely replaced by H2O. The operating conditions employed in the last period were exactly identical to those employed in the first. Fig. 13 reveals that water does not only accelerate catalyst deactivation but also has a negative kinetic effect. This last statement can be clearly observed by comparing the two last presented periods. These two observations are in accordance with the work from Sughrue and Bartholomew [73] in which they also found that, between 498 and 573K, water inhibited the methanation rate on Ni/Al2O3 catalysts and, in some cases, it was causing an irreversible loss of catalyst activity. Unfortunately, the results presented in this section cannot explain this detrimental effect of water on catalyst stability. Water has shown to decrease the amount of surface carbon species and has not shown to induce sintering of the nickel particles at the employed reaction conditions. At this point, the authors can speculate that, likewise cobalt-supported FT catalysts, water enhances the formation of inactive nickel-support species. However, these species were not detectable by XRD. In the present paper, the authors present an additional explanation for this controversial effect of water on catalyst deactivation. It was previously suggested by Iglesia et al. [83] that water can destroy the metal-support interaction present in titania-supported ruthenium-based FT catalysts. In a similar manner, we also suggest that water can oxidize the TiO x (x <2) species formed after reduction of the catalyst at high temperatures. These TiO x species are believed to enhance the rate of CO dissociation by accepting oxygen atoms on the nickel-support interface [47,84]. Moreover, according to Sughrue et al. [73], CO dissociation is co-rate limiting step at the employed reaction temperature. Thereby, it would not be surprising to observe an important decline in activity if this SMSI is disappearing. It is therefore, that we decided to further study the effect of water on catalyst samples reduced at 573K, temperature at which this SMSI is not present [47] or present in a lesser extent. In that sense, if the aforementioned explanation is valid, a lesser detrimental effect of water on catalyst stability would be observed on catalysts reduced at low temperature. This additional insight on the effect of water on catalyst stability is presented in the following section. 3.5 Effect of the reduction temperature The 20Ni/TiO2 batch 2 catalyst was reduced in situ at two different temperatures (573 and 773K) and tested at the same reaction conditions in order to study the effect of the reduction temperature on the activity and the stability of the catalyst. In Fig. 14 the CO conversion during the first 24h of methanation synthesis is presented for these two experiments. As it can be observed, the activity of the catalyst is significantly higher after reduction at 773K. This observation can be explained by the difference between the metal dispersion values obtained after reduction at these two temperatures (see Table 5), which indicates that, most probably, the metal-support interaction is stronger on the sample reduced at 773K. Fig. 14 also reveals that the loss of CO conversion is more severe on the sample reduced at 773K. This phenomenon may be explained with the fact that the sample reduced at 773K led to a considerably higher CO conversion and thus, it was exposed to higher water partial pressure. In the previous section, we suggested that water could destroy the SMSI present on Ni/TiO2 catalysts and so enhance catalyst deactivation. In order to evaluate this, different water and helium feed concentrations were employed on a longer test, however using the 20Ni/TIO2 batch 2 catalyst reduced at 573K. Fig. 15 presents the CO conversion as a function of time on stream for these periods in which water and helium were co-fed with synthesis gas. In the first presented period the synthesis gas feed contained 20% He. In the last period, the synthesis gas feed contained 10% He and 10% H2O. Fig. 15 shows that water has a negative kinetic effect but no clear enhancement of catalyst deactivation. This second observation is in discordance with the results presented in Fig. 13, in which water clearly accelerates catalyst deactivation. In other words, water only showed a clear detrimental effect on the catalyst reduced at 773K, which presents a stronger metal-support interaction. In order to further support the hypothesis that water enhances the oxidation of TiO x species, the authors of the present work studied, by means of H2 static chemisorption, the change in metallic surface area with reaction time on stream. As mentioned previously, these TiO x species do not only favor CO dissociation but also inhibit the chemisorption of H2 on the nickel surface. In consequence, it is expected to observe an increase in the estimated metallic surface area if water oxidizes these TiO x species. For this purpose, a catalyst sample was reduced in H2 for 4h at 773K and analyzed in a Micromeritics ASAP 2020C unit. After this first analysis, the methanation synthesis was performed in the same unit at atmospheric pressure, 583K and a H2/CO=3 for two reaction periods of 5min with intermediate H2 static chemisorption analyses. In Table 7 , the metallic surface area is presented for different reaction times on stream. As it can be observed, there is an increase of the estimated nickel surface area during reaction. 4 Conclusions In this work, a systematic study was performed on titania-supported nickel catalysts in order to evaluate the effect of different process conditions on the stability of these catalysts and mainly, on carbon formation. In addition, longer reaction tests were carried out in order to compare the observations derived from the systematic study with those observed at longer reaction times on stream. It was found that the inlet H2/CO ratio has a clear effect on both the amount and type of carbon species formed on the catalyst surface. The lower the H2/CO ratio the larger and the more stable is the carbon formed. The results of this study also revealed that the syngas partial pressure has again, a significant effect on carbon formation. The rate of carbon deposition is considerably lower at 20bar than at atmospheric pressure. As a result, the inlet H2/CO ratio has a less significant effect on carbon deposition when operating at high syngas partial pressures. Moreover, the effect of temperature on catalyst deactivation and carbon formation was assessed both at atmospheric pressure and at 20bar. In the systematic study performed at atmospheric pressure it was found that, for the studied temperature range (553–613K), the rate polymeric carbon formation increases significantly with temperature. This observation was in accordance with the clear enhancement of the deactivation rate with temperature at 20bar. The presence of water was found to decrease the rate of carbon deposition. Nevertheless, it accelerated catalyst deactivation. In addition, it was shown that water did not induce sintering of the nickel particles. Therefore, the authors suggest that, among other possible deactivation causes such as formation of inactive metal-support compounds, water is destroying the SMSI present on titania-supported nickel catalysts. This statement was supported by two different observations. On one hand, water presented a lesser, or even negligible detrimental effect on catalyst deactivation when the catalyst was reduced at 573K, temperature at which the catalyst probably presents a lower degree of reduction of TiO2 to TiO x (x <2). On the other hand, it was shown that the metallic surface area estimated by H2 chemisorption increased after methanation synthesis, fact that indicates that the water produced during reaction partially destroyed this SMSI. coredata.dc:description: A systematic study on titania-supported nickel catalysts was performed in order to evaluate the effect of different process conditions on catalyst stability. Reaction tests and temperature-programmed-hydrogenation analyses were used in order to evaluate the effect of temperature, feed composition, water and reduction conditions on catalyst deactivation and carbon deposition. It was shown that high H2/CO ratios and syngas partial pressures decrease the rate of carbon formation. Moreover, increasing temperature enhanced the formation of more stable carbon species and thus catalyst deactivation. The temperature-programmed hydrogenation analyses also revealed that water reduces the rate of carbon deposition. However, water enhanced catalyst deactivation when the catalysts were reduced at high temperatures. This negative effect of water is probably due to a progressive destruction of the strong-metal-support interaction characteristic of titania-supported nickel catalysts reduced at high temperatures.
coredata.dc:title: CO methanation over TiO2-supported nickel catalysts: A carbon formation study
